Since 1968, the Council of Ministers has the power to restore rights to criminals, with various governors making changes to make them more difficult or easier. These changes were not always on party lines: Chilean democratic law strengthened the rules, while Republicans extended Bush's pocket, although advocates pushed for further reforms. In April 2007, under Christ ' s guidance, Christ and the Council of Ministers agreed to relax the rules so as to make it easier for criminals to regain their civil rights, including the right to vote. (Krist was a Republican at the time, and now he's running as a Democrat to get his old job back.) This step was defended by Christ in a 2007 op-ed article: "Some who prefer the current system say that the restoration of civil rights is somehow "vulnerable to the crime," as if the restoration of the right to vote, jury service or employment reduces punishment or encourages a person to commit new crimes. In fact, the opposite should be true. Giving a person a meaningful way to return to society, earning a living and participating in our democracy will encourage good behaviour." In the context of the 2007 changes, there were specific rules for three levels of offenders who could apply for their rights. All of them had first to terminate their sentences, including conditional release and restitution of rights.
